Editor’s choice paper Enhanced thermal stability of CeO2-ZrO2-Nd2O3 composite by adding surfactant and its supported Rh-only three-way catalyst Su-Ning Wang a Meng-Meng Sun d Mu-Lan Huang b Tian-Qiong Cheng b Jian-Li Wang b c Shan-Dong Yuan d Yao-Qiang Chen a b c d ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China College of Chemical Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China b Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry & Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry & Technology Ministry of Education College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China c Center of Engineering of Environmental Catalytic Material, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China Center of Engineering of Environmental Catalytic Material Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China d Institute of New Energy and Low-carbon Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China Institute of New Energy and Low-carbon Technology Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China; Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry & Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China; Center of Engineering of Environmental Catalytic Material, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China; Institute of New Energy and Low-carbon Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China. Graphical abstract The nano-architectured CeO2-ZrO2-Nd2O3 composite oxide support materials were successfully synthesized by a co-precipitation combined with a simple mechanical mixing with a serious amount of trialkyl amine (N235, N (C n H2n+1), n =8–10), and the obtained Rh-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity and thermal stability. Ceria-zirconia-neodymia composites are synthesized by a co-precipitation combined with mechanical mixing of trialkyl amine (N235, N (C n H2n+1), n =8–10) process and the effect of the novel surfactant N235 on the properties of ceria-zirconia-neodymia composites and their supported Rh-only three-way catalysts are investigated. The physicochemical properties of the samples before and after aging treatment are characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), oxygen storage capacity (OSC), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), particle size distribution analysis and CO chemisorption. The results indicate that the introduction of surfactant N235 is beneficial to form loose and porous morphology, which contributes to the high surface area, large OSC, superior redox property and high Rh dispersion, and thus the improved catalytic activity for Rh-only three-way catalyst is obtained. The more dosage of N235, the superior catalytic performance for Rh catalyst is. The modified support material (the molar ratio of N235 and total metals is 0.21:1) displays relatively better textural, structural, redox and OSC properties, and the corresponding fresh (Rh/CZN3f) and aged (Rh/CZN3a) catalysts deliver superior catalytic activity. Keywords Ceria-zirconia-neodymia Surfactant Thermal stability Rh-only three-way catalyst 1 Introduction The three-way catalyst (TWC) converter, which has been in active use since 1975, is one of the most innovative technologies for controlling vehicle emissions [1–3]. When the gasoline engine is operated at the theoretical air/fuel (A/F) ratio around 14.6, the TWC allows simultaneous and effective conversions of nitrogen oxide (NO), carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrocarbon (HC) to innoxious compounds [4]. Precious group metals (PGMs) such as Pt, Pd, and Rh are employed in TWCs as active species [5,6]. The total demand of PGMs for automotive catalysts is growing due to the increasing of automobile use and the strengthening of legislation [7]. However, because of their rarity and cost, reducing the consumption of PGMs in automotive catalysts is strongly demanded. Among these PGMs, Rh is the scarcest, and no alternative material could substitute for Rh, which is the primary composition of the TWCs for controlling NO emission [5,8]. From a practical point of view, restraining the deactivation of the catalyst is a crucial and effective strategy for decreasing the usage of Rh. Hence, developing Rh-based TWC with enhanced activity and stability are highly desired. Studies have found that the thermal stability of the oxide support material is a critical factor because the poor thermal stability will severely influence Rh dispersion and reducibility, which leads directly to the degradation of catalytic performance [8,9]. Ferrandon and Krause [10] reported a Rh/La-Al2O3 catalyst with high Rh dispersion before and after aging among the catalysts of Rh/La-Al2O3, Rh/Y-ZrO2, Rh/GdCeO2, Rh/γ-Al2O3, and Rh/CaAl12O19. Morikawa et al. [8] developed a La2O3-stabilized ZrO2 support which contains a Nd2O3-enriched surface layer and nanosized Al2O3. They found that the Al2O3 diffusion barrier could suppress the sintering of La2O3-stabilized ZrO2 and thus enhance the durability and thermal stability of the Rh-based TWC catalyst. Compared with other support materials, ceria-zirconia solid solution composites oxide, which can effectively mitigate the fluctuation in the air/fuel (A/F) ratio of the catalyst inlet gas, has also been studied as a promising support for an Rh catalyst [11,12], especially the Zr-based support because of their excellent textural performances, good ageing resistance and redox properties [13]. However, the properties of the materials are found to be mainly determined by the preparation method and process route. Recently, numerous literatures have reported that the assistance of surfactant during the preparation process is an effective approach because the surfactant has a positive effect on the pore features and the defects in the lattice of the mesostructured composites [14–16]. Herein, a series of ceria-zirconia-neodymia composite oxides are synthesized by co-precipitation combined with a simple mechanical mixing process, in which a series of amount of surfactant trialkyl amine (N235, N (C n H2n+1), n =8–10) is used to investigate the influence of N235 on the properties of the ceria-zirconia-neodymia mixed oxides and their supported Rh-only three-way catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of ceria-zirconia-neodymia composite The samples were synthesized via a co-precipitation method combined with a simple mechanical mixing process, and the Ce2(CO3)3, Zr(CO3)2 and Nd(NO3)3·6H2O were used as raw materials. Firstly, Ce2(CO3)3 and Zr(CO3)2 were dissolved in the concentrated nitric acid, respectively. Then Nd(NO3)3·6H2O and a moderate amount of H2O2 were added into the above solution with a nominal composition (mass components of 18.6% CeO2, 74.4% ZrO2 and 7% Nd2O3) to form mixed solution. Firstly, 3L of distilled water was added in to a reactor. Then mixed solution and the desired amount of NH3·H2O and (NH4)2CO3 (molar ratio 1:1) were simultaneously pumped into the reactor. All of these procedures were performed under an intensive stirring at about 1000rpm. Afterwards, the resulting co-precipitated precursors were filtered and washed. The obtained filter cake was drastically mixed with trialkyl amine (N235, N (C n H2n+1), n=8–10), and the ratios moles of N235 to moles of total metals were 0, 0.07, 0.14, 0.21 and 0.28, respectively. The mixtures were dried at 70°C for 12h, and the samples were labeled as CZN-70, CZN1-70, CZN2-70, CZN3-70 and CZN4-70, respectively. The as-received powders were heat-treated in a muffle furnace at 600°C in air for 3h to obtain the mixed oxide, which were labeled as CZN-600, CZN1-600, CZN2-600, CZN3-600 and CZN4-600, respectively. In order to investigate the effect of N235 on the thermal stability of CeO2-ZrO2-Nd2O3 composite materials, all samples were calcined at 1000°C for 5h and they were marked as CZN-1000, CZN1-1000, CZN2-1000, CZN3-1000 and CZN4-1000, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The as-prepared CZN-600, CZN1-600, CZN2-600, CZN3-600 and CZN4-600 materials were used as the carriers to support the active constituent Rh. A traditional wet impregnation method was employed and the theoretical loading contents of Rh were 0.47wt% for all catalysts. The detailed preparation procedure was similar to the literature [5]. The fresh catalysts calcined at 550°C for 3h were designated as Rh/CZNf, Rh/CZN1f, Rh/CZN2f, Rh/CZN3f and Rh/CZN4f, respectively. Moreover, the obtained fresh catalyst was annealed at 1000°C for 5h in air to get the aged catalysts, which were denoted as Rh/CZNa, Rh/CZN1a, Rh/CZN2a, Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a, respectively. 2.3 Characterization techniques The textural and structural properties of the samples were identified by N2 adsorption-desorption (Quantachrome SI) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, Philips Company, PW 1730) using a Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154178nm) analyses. Thermogravimetric (TG) and Differential Thermal analysis (DTA) were conducted on a STA 449 analyzer (Netzsch). The surface content of element and its valence state for the samples were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, British Kratos XSAM-800 electron spectrometer equipped with Mg Kα source of 1253.6eV) measurement. The redox property, oxygen storage capacity and CO chemisorption were performed on a self-assembled experimental instrument equipped with a gas chromatograph. The morphology and particle size of the samples were observed by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, using a Hitachi S-4800 instrument with the acceleration voltage of 5.0kV), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN with the accelerating voltage of 200kV) and Malvern laser particle size analyzer. The details of the characterization techniques are shown in the supplementary information. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The activity of as-prepared Rh-based three-way catalyst was evaluated in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor with a gas mixture that simulated the automotive exhaust. The catalyst (0.25mL) was held in a stainless tube. The reaction gas was a mixture of CO (0.50%), C3H8 (0.045%), NO (0.06%), CO2 (10%), H2O (10%), O2 (adjustable) and N2 was used as a diluent. The feed stream was regulated with special mass flow controllers before entering into the reactor and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was maintained at 40,000h−1. The inlet and outlet gas compositions were monitored by an FGA-4100 analyzer (Foshan Analyticla Instrument Co., Ltd. China), and accordingly the conversions of NO, CO and C3H8 were calculated. The λ value of the simulated exhaust, which represents the ratio between the available oxygen and the oxygen needed for full conversions to H2O, CO2 and N2, can be defined by the following Eq. (1): (1) λ={2[O2]+[NO]}/{10[C3H8]+[CO]} The catalyst was pretreated under the reactive atmosphere at 550°C for 1h. Then the catalyst was cooled to the appropriate measurement temperature and λ=1 was employed at each testing point. 3 Results and discussions The textural performances for all the samples before and after aging are listed in Table 1 . Notice that all the N235 assisted fresh samples display higher specific surface area and larger pore volume than CZN-600, demonstrating that the textural property is predominated by the presence of N235. Comparing with the corresponding fresh ones, a clear defined decrease in surface area and pore volume is observed in aged samples. This result stems from the sintering effect for the samples exposed to prolonged high temperature calcination [5,17]. The percentage surface area loss compared with the fresh state (ΔSBET%) could be an indicator of thermal stability [18]. It can be seen from Table 1 that the ΔSBET% of CZN-600, CZN1-600, CZN2-600, CZN3-600 and CZN4-600 are 81.69%, 78.67%, 69.14%, 66.30% and 65.26% for, respectively. Furthermore, the pore volume of the samples increase in the order: CZN4-1000>CZN3-1000>CZN2-1000>CZN1-1000>CZN-1000, indicating the highest thermal stability for CZN4-1000 among all the samples. Interestingly, it shows that the specific surface area and pore volume of the fresh and aged samples are increased obviously with the addition amount of N235 increasing from 0 to 0.21, whereas this increasing trend is not distinct when the usage amount of N235 increase from 0.21 to 0.28. Hence, the relatively higher textural performances of CZN3-1000 (31m2 g−1 and 0.145mLg−1) and CZN4-1000 (33m2 g−1 and 0.148mLg−1) maybe deliver the enhanced catalytic performance because of their high surface area and large pore volume. Figs. 1 and S1 show pore size distributions of the as-prepared samples and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. The isotherms for all the samples (see Fig. S1 in supplementary information) belong to the “type IV” class according to the IUPAC definition, indicating the existence of mesoporous with network in the support materials [19]. The analogous characteristics of the pore size distributions can be observed from Fig. 1. The pore diameters of CZN3-600 and CZN4-600 are mainly distributed between 4 and 9nm, much wider and larger than that of CZN-600 (3–6nm). The pore diameters of all the aged sample is increased after the sintering process due to the agglomeration of nanoparticles. However, the pore size distribution for CZN3-1000 and CZN4-1000 is distinctively different with the other three aged samples, indicating the disparity of the accumulation mode for the nanoparticles among the samples during sintering process. XRD diffraction patterns of the dried precursors, fresh and aged support materials are present in Fig. 2 . It can be observed that the precursors present poor crystallinity, which related to the formation of nanostructure [20]. The profiles of all dried precipitates are the feature of cubic Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 structure with Fm–3m space group. No characteristic peaks of ZrO2 phases are discovered, indicating that the residual zirconium is primarily existed in an amorphous form, which is well dispersed in grain boundaries [21]. After calcinated at 600°C, the mixed oxides, which were obtained from the completely transformation of dried precipitates (see Fig. S2), feature the typical reflections of a single tetragonal phase Ce0.15Zr0.85O2 (space group P42/nmc, ICSD No. 41580). It can be seen from Fig. 2(b) that all reflection peaks slightly shift to lower 2θ degree regions compared to those for the standard Ce0.15Zr0.85O2, indicating that neodymium ions are totally incorporated into the tetragonal lattice and thus enlarge the crystal lattice as the ionic radius of Nd3+ (1.00Å) is larger than that of Ce4+ (0.97Å) and Zr4+ (0.84Å) [22]. For the aged samples, all diffraction patterns become sharper and more intense, particularly the CZN-1000, declaring the formation of larger crystallites owing to the grain growth during the aging process [18]. Moreover, the diffraction peak of CZN-1000 shifts to lower angle and the pattern resembles that of tetragonal Ce0.18Zr0.82O2, which hints us that the migration of Zr towards the periphery of the particles during aging treatment, further confirming the inferior structural thermal stability for CZN-1000. The crystallite sizes of the aged samples, which were calculated according to Scherer equation, are listed in Table S2. Multiples of crystal growth for the fresh and aged samples based on the corresponding crystallite size for dried materials are shown in Fig. S3. During the thermal treatment, the growth rates for the samples are quite different. The material without the assistance of N235 (CZN) is the fastest while CZN4 (similar with CZN3) is the slowest. In conclusion, the sintering and agglomeration of the ceria-zirconia-neodymia composite could be mitigated during high temperature calcination with the assistance of N235. The surface content of Rh as well as the surface atom ratio of Zr/Ce and Ce3+ in Ce are investigated and the related data are listed in Table S3. The Ce 3d and Rh 3d spectra over the fresh and aged catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 3 and Fig. S4, respectively. For fresh catalyst, the surface atom ratios of Zr/Ce are between 5.62 and 5.64, closing to the theoretical value 5.67, which means the Zr and Ce atoms are homogeneously distributed on the surface of the mixed oxide. The surface concentrations of Ce3+ in Ce increases with the amount of N235. The existence of Ce3+ is related to the formation of oxygen vacancy, which is an indispensable factor that affects the oxygen mobility. The aging induced effects can be seen from XPS data when comparing the aged catalysts with the fresh ones. The ratio of Zr/Ce for Rh/CZNa (6.29) is the largest among the five aged catalyst. The extent of the enlargement is gradually retarded with the increase of the amount of N235. Previous studies [23,24] have shown that during elevated temperature treatment, a portion of Zr may migrate from the bulk to the surface and thus result in the enlargement of Zr/Ce on the crystal surface, which could reduce the structural stability. An obvious decline of Ce3+ fraction can be clearly seen for the aged catalysts because of particle sintering. The Ce3+ contents follow the sequence of Rh/CZN4a≈Rh/CZN3a>Rh/CZN2a>Rh/CZN1a>Rh/CZNa. Hence, based on the analysis above, the N235 assistance could effectively promote the thermal stability as well as the Ce3+ fraction of the mixed oxides. It can be seen in Table S3 that the surface content of Rh shows an increasing tendency from Rh/CZNf to Rh/CZN4f. After higher temperature treatment, conspicuous reduction of surface Rh concentration is found for all catalysts. Two influencing factors mainly contribute to this reduction: one is the sintering of Rh species during calcination, and the other one is the encapsulation of Rh because of the aggregation of the support materials. The surface content of Rh for Rh/CZN4a is 0.56, much higher than that for Rh/CZNa (0.19). Rhodium 3d XPS spectra for catalysts before and after aging are shown in Fig. S4. It can be seen from Fig. S4(a) that the five fresh catalysts possess faint peaks at about 307eV (Rh 3d5/2), indicating the presence of slight metallic Rh. Besides, prominent peaks at about 308eV (Rh 3d5/2) could be clearly observed, which is in good agreement with the literature data for Rh2O3 [25,26]. The existence of the oxide phase is perfectly reasonable as the catalysts are treated at 550°C in air. Upon aging treatment, the peaks of Rh 3d5/2 are shifted to higher binding energies, suggesting the formation of irreducible oxide phase of RhO2 [11,26]. The relative amount of Rh4+ for Rh/CZNa (32.7%) is the largest (see Fig. S5 and Table S3), indicating the least amount of exploitable Rh species in Rh/CZNa. The reduction properties of the support materials calcinated at 600 and 1000°C are shown in Fig. 4 and their peak temperature maxima and quantitative analyses of H2 consumption, which were calibrated with a standard CuO sample, are collected in Table S4. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the five fresh samples possess a broad unsymmetrical peak below 600°C associated with the reduction of surface Ce4+ and bulk Ce4+ [27,28]. CZN-600 shows a poor reduction ability because of the highest reduction temperature (i.e. 583°C) among the samples. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the reduction peaks for the aged materials shift to higher temperature when compared with their corresponding fresh samples, especially for CZN-1000 (699°C), which is much higher than that for CZN-600 (583°C). The amount of total H2 consumption and reduction ratios increase in the order: CZN-1000<CZN1-1000<CZN2-1000<CZN3-1000<CZN4-1000 (see Table S4). It is noticeable that the N235 is in favor of the relatively low-temperature reduction peaks and large total H2 consumptions for the other four aged samples. H2-TPR profiles of the Rh-supported catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . Profiles of fresh catalysts present one broad peak dominated low-temperature reduction feature at approximately 200°C, which is assigned to the reduction of RhO x species and spill-over of hydrogen onto the support materials from RhO x [29]. After thermal aging, three reduction peaks could be observed, which are labled as peak α, β and γ, respectively. Peak α is generally assigined to the reduction of well-dispersed Rh2O3, peak β is associated with the reduction of large Rh2O3 crystals and peak γ is attributed to the reduction of Rh2O3 that interacted with the support materials [8,30]. The change from one broad peak (see Fig. 5(a)) to three or two peaks (see Fig. 5(b)) could be attributed to the agglomeration and sintering of the noble metals and support materials [20]. Rh/CZN2a, Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a possess two reduction peaks with lower temperature compared with the other two aged catalysts. The very low surface areas of CZN-1000 and CZN1-1000 could restrict the homogeneous distribution of the Rh species, thus impair the reduction ability. Furthermore, the shape of the reduction profiles for Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a is similar to the corresponding fresh ones, demonstrating the superior thermal stability of reduction performance for Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a. OSC performance is one of the crucial factors for ceria-zirconia solids, and OSC material functions as an oxygen buffer for TWCs. The quantitative analysis results of OSC for the support materials are illustrated in Table S5. For the fresh samples, the N235 assisted materials present slightly higher OSC than CZN-600. With regard to the aged support materials, a dramatic decline in OSC values is observed, especially CZN-1000. The OSC values standardized by Ce content and the oxidation ratios are also calculated and collected in Table S5. It can be clearly seen that the experimental OSC values are lower than the theoretical values (0.25mol O2/mol CeO2), and the oxidation ratio displays an obviously incremental tendency with the proportion of N235, indicating that the surfactant of N235 could strongly improve the thermal stability of OSC. It should be noted that only a small enhancement is observed with increasing N235 addition proportion from 0.21 to 0.28 (ratios moles of N235 to moles of total metals). The morphology analysis of the samples before and after aging is shown in Figs. 6 and 7 . It can be seen from Fig. 6 that CZN-600 exhibits a large agglomerates with compact feature, which contains numerous primary nanoparticles. The accumulation become looser and more porous with the increasing of dosage for N235. The surfactant N235 may retard the shrinkage and collapse of the network during drying and calcination and consequently modify the stack mode. In addition, N235 would be decomposed into gases and create pores during calcination procedure, which is conducive to maintain sparse accumulation feature. Hence, the assistance of N235 is in favor of high surface area and large pore volume. Compared with the corresponding fresh samples, the aged ones present larger particles and lesser pores (see Fig. 6) owing to severe sintering have been occurred, which is in good accordance with the resuls of particle sizes analysis (see Fig. S6 and Table S6). In addition, the densely aggregated features may inhibit the lattice oxygen migration and thus resulting in poor reduction and low OSC performance [31]. CZN-1000 shows a compact appearance with large particles and a voidless structure (see Figs. 6 and 7), while CZN3-1000 and CZN4-1000 still exhibit the sparsely agglomerated morphology, which is similar to CZN3-600 and CZN4-600, respectively. Fig. S8 displays the Rh dispersion on the fresh and aged catalysts. For fresh catalysts, Rh/CZN3f and Rh/CZN4f exhibit the highest Rh dispersion (23.2% and 23.6%). After durability treatment, the Rh dispersion of the five aged catalysts degrade significantly, which is mainly due to the sintering: (i) loss of surface area for support materials owing to pore collapse and the encapsulation of noble metals resulting from the sintering process, (ii) crystallite growth of the support and the precious metals [32]. Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a possess about four times of the Rh dispersion of Rh/CZNa, and this result is in accordance with the TEM analysis (see Fig. S7). With the contribution of N235, the sparsely-agglomerated morphology could strongly restrain the pore collapse and the crystallite growth of the support mixed oxides. The results are consistent with the H2-TPR analysis [10]. The NO, CO and C3H8 conversions as a function of temperature under stoichiometric NO+CO+C3H8 +O2 reaction conditions over the fresh and aged catalyst are shown in Fig. 8 , and the corresponding light-off temperatures (T 50%) are displayed in Fig. 9 . From Fig. 8, a significant promoting effect of N235 on the activity of the fresh and aged Rh-based TWCs can be clearly observed. This behavior could be correlated well with morphology features of the support materials. The loose and porous morphology with the assistance of N235, especially for CZN3-600 and CZN4-600, is beneficial to enhance the sintering resistance for the supports, which exhibit high surface area, large pore volume, high Ce3+ content and small particle size, thus high redox property, large OSC, high Rh dispersion and high content of reducible Rh species are obtained. It suggests that the catalytic performance of the catalysts mainly depends on Rh dispersion and Rh valence state, which is strongly affected by the properties of the support materials. The high dispersion of Rh could provide more active site and the Rh3+ is more facilitate to reduce to metallic Rh [8,33]. It can be known from Fig. 9 that the T 50% values of noxious reactants decrease when the proportion of N235 increases from 0 to 0.21, while an indistinctive decrease with the further increase of N235 amount. Compared with the fresh catalysts, the T 50% for aged catalysts raise to higher temperature, and the deteriorated catalytic activity for the aged catalysts is principally due to the sintering of support materials and the precious metal species, as well as the oxidation of Rh to irreducible Rh4+. The T 50% of NO and CO for Rh/CZNa are 278°C and 280°C, respectively, much higher than those of Rh/CZN3a and Rh/CZN4a (NO T 50% =229°C, CO T 50% =235°C; NO T 50% =226°C, CO T 50% =230°C), implying the superior thermal stability of the catalyst with the assistance of N235. A point should be note is that the conversions of C3H8 for the aged catalysts are really poor and the T 50% are higher than 450°C (see Fig. 8), although the catalytic performance for C3H8 is follow the sequence: Rh/CZN4a>Rh/CZN3a>Rh/CZN2a>Rh/CZN1a>Rh/CZNa. A full TWC comprising Rh/OSC+ Pd/Al2O3 are provided (see Fig. S9), the conversions of NO, CO and C3H8 over Pd-Rh/CZN3f and Pd-Rh/CZN3a are superior to those of Pd-Rh/CZNf and Pd-Rh/CZNa, respectively. These results indicate that, as a Rh support, the performance of the oxygen storage material is enhanced by the modification of N235. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully developed a facile and widely applicable method for the preparation of ceria-zirconia-neodymia composites with highly thermal stability, in which the surfactant N235 plays a crucial role, and they were employed as support for Rh-based three-way catalyst. The physicochemical properties for the supports and the corresponding catalysts are characterized. The results indicate that: (1) Employment of N235 leads to the enhanced textural and structural performances. (2) Combined with the results of SEM and TEM, it can be suggested that the surfactant N235 could modify the stack mode for the materials, which present loose accumulation features. (3) The sparsely agglomerated morphology is beneficial to the higher reducibility, larger OSC as well as higher Rh dispersion and improved three-way catalytic activity. (4) The modified support material with 0.21 proportion of N235 addition displays superior textural, structural, redox and OSC properties, and Rh/CZN3-f and Rh/CZN3-a deliver superior catalytic activity. Author contributions The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given the approval to the final version of the manuscript. Conflict of interest The authors declare no competing financial interest. Acknowledgement We gratefully acknowledge the National High Technology Research and Development Program of China (863 Program, 2015AA034603) for their generous financial supports to our research. Appendix A Supplementary data Textural characteristics of fresh and aged catalysts, Crystallite sizes of samples calcined at different temperatures, surface content of Rh and surface atomic ratios derived from XPS analyses, the reduction peak temperatures and quantitative analysis results of H2-TPR for the samples, the quantitative analysis results of OSC for the samples, D10, D50 and D90 derived from the particle size analyses, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the fresh and aged samples, TG/DTA curves, multiples of crystal growth for the fresh and aged samples based on the corresponding crystallite size for dried materials, Rh 3d XPS spectra of fresh and aged catalysts, particle size distribution patterns of support materials, TEM images of the aged catalysts, Rh dispersion of fresh and aged catalysts, conversion curves of NO, CO and C3H8 over Rh/OSC+Pd/Al2O3 catalysts. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2017.01.015. coredata.dc:description: Ceria-zirconia-neodymia composites are synthesized by a co-precipitation combined with mechanical mixing of trialkyl amine (N235, N (C n H2n+1), n =8–10) process and the effect of the novel surfactant N235 on the properties of ceria-zirconia-neodymia composites and their supported Rh-only three-way catalysts are investigated. The physicochemical properties of the samples before and after aging treatment are characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), oxygen storage capacity (OSC), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), particle size distribution analysis and CO chemisorption. The results indicate that the introduction of surfactant N235 is beneficial to form loose and porous morphology, which contributes to the high surface area, large OSC, superior redox property and high Rh dispersion, and thus the improved catalytic activity for Rh-only three-way catalyst is obtained. The more dosage of N235, the superior catalytic performance for Rh catalyst is. The modified support material (the molar ratio of N235 and total metals is 0.21:1) displays relatively better textural, structural, redox and OSC properties, and the corresponding fresh (Rh/CZN3f) and aged (Rh/CZN3a) catalysts deliver superior catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced thermal stability of CeO2-ZrO2-Nd2O3 composite by adding surfactant and its supported Rh-only three-way catalyst
